comments.html:
Ivan,

Thanks for the opportunity to do this. I really enjoyed it, and I hope we get the chance to do it again.

Cheers
Peter Jones
http://about.me/petergjones
comments.name: Peter Jones

comments.html: No. FPGA is programmable at the silicon gate level, while programmable ASIC could be programmable at the level of "which fields do I use for lookup". Gross oversimplification, but I hope you get the difference.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: Best analogy I can think of is shader programing for graphics processing units. Still application specific with programmability.
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html: programmable ASIC is a marketing name for a FGPA?
comments.name: apezuela

comments.html:
Ivan is close to correct. FPGAs have a huge amount of flexibility at the logical gate level, but you pay for that in terms of price/poerformance.
Programmable ASICs support certain types of primitives designed for dealing with packet forwarding operations.

Take a look at http://techfieldday.com/appearance/cisco-enterprise-switching-presents-at-tech-field-day-extra-at-cisco-live-berlin/ and http://techfieldday.com/video/programmable-asics-for-cisco-catalyst-switches-with-muhammad-imam/ for more info.
comments.name: Peter Jones
